title: Active ETF pause not about conflicts: Magellan
text:
ASIC’s carefully worded notice to market participants ordered a pause on the listing of “managed funds that do not disclose their portfolio holdings daily and have internal market makers”, meaning the fund manager quotes buy and sell prices for its own fund.

BetaShares chief executive Alex Vynokur, whose business primarily operates passive ETFs with external market makers but also offers a small number of active ETFs with internal market makers, said the conflicts in the current system are “manageable”.

BestaShares chief executive Alex Vynokur is inspired by the Canadian regulatory framework for active ETFs. Dominic Lorrimer

“I don’t think there is a major issue, but you could perceive a conflict where a manager is doing everything — both managing the money and acting as market maker — and you could ask whether prices are therefore being set fairly and reasonably,” Mr Vynokur told The Australian Financial Review.

More so than conflict mitigation, or even trying to increase transparency, Mr Vynokur suggested ASIC’s intervention on active ETFs is mostly about quality control.

“Most capable active managers are now thinking about [launching] an ETF,” he said. “Whilst the current set of rules are robust, ETFs is a specialist area and you have fund managers who are not specialists viewing an exchange as just another distribution strategy.”

Of the $56.2 billion total ETF market capitalisation in Australia, BetaShares estimates that $3.7 billion is now in actively managed products.

Mr Vynokur said ASIC has done a “commendable” job in ensuring the floodgates are not opened entirely to fund managers seeking an active ETF option, some of which he said have investment strategies without the appropriate liquidity profile to be listed on an exchange.

Advertisement

International inspiration

Mr Vynokur believes there are legitimate reasons why an active manager, especially a top-performing one like Magellan, would be hesitant to disclose its portfolio to an external market maker. To do so could effectively turn its most lucrative asset, its intellectual property, into a publicly viewable index.

But he also suggested there are a number of ways transparency can be enhanced without giving away its trade secrets.

One is to ensure structural separation between the money manager and market maker. For example, BetaShares acts as market maker for the five active ETFs in the market, while AMP Capital and Legg Mason run the portfolios for three and five of the products respectively.

Another alternative may lie in adopting models being experimented with overseas, such as an increasingly common practice in Canada of active managers disclosing portfolios to external market makers under a formal non-disclosure agreement, without disclosing publicly to the broader market.

ASIC has also flagged “recent international developments” including new regulatory frameworks for active ETFs in Hong Kong and the US as one of the factors in its decision to order the pause.

A consultation is under way with market participants and the pause is expected to last for the remainder of the 2019 calendar year.
description: Is ASIC's temporary suspension on the $3.7 billion active exchange traded fund market just a routine reset or a sign it has serious concerns?
